ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This was my favorite course of the semester! I enjoyed all the readings and classroom discussions. Everyone in the class had insightful comments to make and students did an excellent job at leading discussions and challenging the group with good questions.

there was too much reading for some weeks. I think the class would be better structured if the first half was lecture and the 2nd half was discussion. That way, the nuances of the articles would be clearer.

The discussions in class enabled to understand conservation issues from various perspectives: politics, economy, history, development etcI would recommend this class for second year students who are interested in conservation and development issues in developing countries.In general, this was one of the best classes I took while at Yale.

On Question 7: During presentations of the topics of our final papers Amity was visibly falling asleep, which aside from being unprofessional was not very reassuring  considering she was going to be assigning us grades ...On Question 8: The readings were excellent and very helpful, although they became redundant after a while. We did not engage with the material analytically. Several rigorous students, including one of the Agrarian Studies fellows, came to the seminar for a few weeks before eventually deciding to drop it, presumably because the course was not sufficiently rigorous to be worth the time. I left the course thinking I could have learned much, much more from the material if we had had better guidance.
The course was well organized and well run. It was great!
Discussions and readings were excellent. It's a 3-hour seminar with lots of time to discuss the complexities of property rights.
Class readings and discussion sections with the rest of classmates

I first thought that property rights were simply an interesting tangent to what I was studying, but I soon found that they are an integral part of a lot of what people at FES are studying, so I was surprised that a course like this had never been taught before. It was new, interesting material.

This has been my favorite course at FES thus far. The best part I thought were actually the first three discussion topics + readings (weeks 2, 3, 4). I liked starting with the underlying theory and re-engaging with thinkers like Locke and Marx which most of us read in undergrad. I also loved picking apart the tragedy of the commons and delving into collective action theory. Just overall, the subject material was positively fascinating.
The readings; in particular these:Carol Rose"Theory of Access"Amanor 2008Zerner 1994Agrawal and Ostrom 2001Ewick and Silbey 1995Orlove 1991
Discussions. But it didn't hurt to have brief presentations and other material to supplement these discussions.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Everything was great.
none, course was great and class size was just right to make things run smoothly and to get the most benefit from them
more explanation from Prof.

The course is a lot of discussion, which, while interesting, is exhausting. Either cut the course to 2 hours or lecture for an hour. WHen the short lecture was added to the end, it made the course a lot better. We also want to hear from the instructor, not just each other.Also, a couple of the weeks got repetitive in terms of content. I think these topics included narratives, traditional land tenure, etc. I think maybe scrap one or integrate it into another. I know the class is international and not about property rights in any one country in particular, but i think we could have one class that would be a kind of case study of property rights in one country, including in-depth analysis of different types of regimes (both traditional and statutory), and also getting into some of the legal cases. A lot of property is legal--just head over to the Law School where they too have a semester-long course on it.

Towards the end of the semester, the readings and topics started to feel a bit redundant (esp. when we got to the politics of representation). It would have been great to spend more time on the modern topics at the end of the course, like carbon rights, bioprospecting, and intellectual property of indigenous knowledge. Maybe next year they can be expanded into two weeks towards the end instead of just one? Also, the mapping exercise was fun  the one where we looked at different maps of New Haven. I highly encourage more fun with maps.

More analysis from someone familiar with the material. Amity left students to wallow around in redundant articlesshe rarely lectured and was moderately incisive when she didand the course very much suffered for it.
Can't think of much

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The instructor was available to talk about paper topics, etc.
great, always available to help students out
both were very available.
The instructor was readily available, which I enjoyed.
Superb. Prof. Doolittle made herself available and incorporated student comments into the running of the course.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: porperty rights falls in directly to the work of my masters thesis as well as my future career aspirations
Property rights (and confusion thereover) is a central theme in my research project and my academic focus on social and political ecology.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Relates to my research interests.
high interest, passion around issues of preprty rights
an interest in how property rights impact other environmental issues.

I am from developing country where complications of property rights on natural resources are central to today's poverty and small-localized conflicts. Understanding such complications is central to solving poverty and at the same time promoting conservation of natural resources, as a result I took this course. Before this course, property rights were just a simple phenomenon to me but right now it appears to be a complex and source of rich/elite to undermine the poor.

To learn about property rights in relation to environmental management and conflict. Also, it seemed well organized, there was an incredible group of students in the course, and the reading list was great.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes!
yes
i didn't know what to expect
YEs, I learned a lot about property rights in itself, but also how it relates to so many other things I'm studying--resource management, justice issues, climate change, etc.
Amity prepared us all very well to expect to be confused, but to learn a lot from our confusion and the process of attemptingto make sense of it all.
The course did not live up to my expectations. I got out of it knowledge of several interesting articles. Not worth a semester's amount of time.
It went far beyond my expectations. I could not have guessed that discussions would be so fruitful and that I would enjoy class so much.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes!
yes, and more

Yes,I took the class in order to understand more on the issues pertaining to conservation and property issues in natural resources management. I got into the class with very little knowledge on these issues. Through discussions with my fellow students and the Professor, I was able to gain more understanding on complications of conservations issues in developing countries
Yes, see above.

I expected not to find answers, and towards the end of the course it definitely felt like we had entered the realm of confusion in that we had a grasp of what was going wrong and why but were pressed to come up with a solution that didnt perpetuate the problem. I think this is one of those cases where it would have been nice to defy expectations instead of meeting them.
Absolutely

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

There were a lot of advantages. For example, in my group people brought their work experiences from various countries (regions) to discussion. This multi-regional experience was helpful to understand various issues and lead class discussions.
Leading discussion in groups of 3 was ideal.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This is an excellent course that allows you to explore the complexities of property rights and how they affect natural resource management regimes. We learn about the different stakeholders that shape these regimes and address power and access. Wonderful course. Would definitely recommend it!
choose a topic/example you are passionate about early one, so you can then apply the theories and readings toyour case throughout the semester

I would advise three things:1: They should take introductory social science/anthropology classes in order to be comfortable with discussions and readings in class2: They should engage fully in discussion in order to benefit from the class3: They should attend talks to engage in a global debates about conservation issues

The best thing anyone can do in this course is to take very seriously their role as discussion leaders when it is their turn to lead class discussion. I think this course succeeded because people did this creatively during the first few weeks and it really set the tone for a whole semester of high quality discussion and engagement.
Make sure to read and analyze and critique on your own if you want anything out of the class.
Try to create a nice report with the other students. Come to class prepared. Push the class discussions so that you're getting the most out of the readings (and your fellow classmates).
